conclusion: For the latch to enter the self-locking condition, the component of the spring force that tends to make the latch slide back up the inclined face must be no larger than the maximum static-friction force that can be developed on that face.

Define variables: k – spring stiffness, x – spring compression when self-locking just occurs, θ – inclination of the latch face (given 30°), μ – coefficient of static friction on the contact face, FN – normal force between the latch face and the groove at point P, Fs – spring force = k x.
Component of spring force normal to the face is Fs sin θ.
Component of spring force tangential to the face (trying to slide the latch up) is Fs cos θ.
At the verge of self-locking, Fs cos θ ≤ μ FN.
From the normal equilibrium, FN = Fs sin θ.
Substitute FN = Fs sin θ in Fs cos θ ≤ μ FN to get Fs cos θ ≤ μ (Fs sin θ) → tan θ ≥ (1/μ).
Self-locking occurs only if μ ≥ cot θ.
At the instant of self-locking the limiting case is μ = cot θ, and the equalities in Fs cos θ ≤ μ FN and FN = Fs sin θ hold.
FN = Fs sin θ = (k x) sin θ.
Once the latch has just reached the self-locking state, the magnitude of the normal force between the latch D and groove E is FN = k x sin θ.
Numeric substitution: with θ = 30°, sin θ = 0.5, so FN = 0.5 k x.
